DataElement.preferredDefinition: A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations. -- 2004:The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance._Characteristics; distinguishing qualities of a person, object, or substance._Configuration of the polyp

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.

Concepts.definition: Not stated explicitly or in detail.
Used to indicate the absence or lack of something or someone.
A slender or elongated structure that supports another usually larger structure.
A lesion connected to the underlying tissue by a small stalk.
Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.
A slender or elongated structure that supports another usually larger structure.
A lesion connected to the underlying tissue by a small stalk.
Attached directly by the base; not having an intervening stalk.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation. Indicators determine or aid in determining whether or not certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied. (On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.
